name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text:
A CASA Advocate‚Äôs involvement is shown to reduce how long a child is in foster care and help to reduce the need for continued intervention.

Maryann has seen her own impact first-hand and we are grateful for her support to so many children in our community.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text:
A special part of being a CASA for Maryann is the opportunity to learn. For her, this has involved educating herself on LGBTQ+ needs.

There are online courses to help CASAs learn about specific subjects to help understand what a child is going through and what they might need.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text:
Maryann‚Äôs first case showed her how CASAs can help a child grow in such a short time.

After their cases are resolved, CASAs end communication with the child. Advocates are often a support system for each other to process their cases and keep eachother going in such tough work.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text:
While social workers and judges work to assist the whole family, CASAs come in to directly work with a child to make sure nothing is forgotten or overlooked.

They are an extra adult to look out for kids and advocate on their behalf.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text:
CASAs go through 30 hours of training and are asked to make visits at least once a month ‚Äì more if needed.

They work with social workers, school guidance counselors, a judge, and a law guardian at times. It is about finding the right balance for each child‚Äôs needs.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text:
Maryann explained that CASAs have a small window of time with a child, between foster care and a permanent home. Which is often when they are most vulnerable.

Her goal is to learn their needs as quickly as possible & bring as much happiness and support to their lives as she can.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text:
Court Appointed Special Advocates is a network of volunteers across 49 states who advocate for foster children, acting as a partner and support system for their needs. 

Maryann volunteers her time with CASA of Ocean County.
https://t.co/uXNnEjDVTZ

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: Al and Marilyn have given so much to so many people over the last few years. We look forward to seeing their continued success improving their neighbors‚Äô lives. https://t.co/5NlWpxZaZs

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: In their virtual two hour class every Tuesday morning, Marilyn and Al present lessons and activities that they spend close to 10 hours preparing beforehand. They both feel it is ‚Äúimmeasurable‚Äù what they get back from the experience of changing their students‚Äô lives. https://t.co/r7VcUhwFy4

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: Since then, their reach has grown and they have successfully created a community of students who can rely on them and their peers to further their education.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: With the support of Literacy NJ, Marilyn and Al decided to begin co-tutoring a class: sharing the class load and developing lesson plans together. In July of 2020, Marilyn and Al were given the opportunity to develop and co-teach their own class within the Literacy NJ program.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: He started sitting in on Literacy NJ‚Äôs virtual English classes, learning how to navigate Zoom when he met Marilyn, a recently retired Humanities and ESL Supervisor and educator in Monmouth County, who was also interested in teaching English and serving her community.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: Al, who retired from the National Weather Service in 2019, was tutoring at the time with Literacy NJ, leaning into his knack for the nuanced rules of the English language. When he could no longer meet with everyone in person, he set out to find another way to continue teaching.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: Before the pandemic, Literacy NJ volunteers hosted English classes in 12 counties, including Burlington and Ocean. When COVID-19 struck, many classes had to shut down. However the need for English classes was greater than ever, especially when all communication went virtual.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: To close this gap, Literacy NJ advocates for increased funding and awareness for literacy issues, they develop instructional materials and train volunteer tutors - like Marilyn and Al - to host classes and work closely with students.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: However, these language and literacy skills do not come naturally and, for a variety of reasons, including English as a second language (ESL), about 16% of adults in New Jersey lack basic English literacy skills. https://t.co/5ibBNlRpf6

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text:
Literacy NJ is a nonprofit organization working to ensure all adults can read, write, and easily communicate with their neighbors. For many native English speakers, it‚Äôs easy to take this part of everyday life for granted.

https://t.co/EUlBjuAXnf

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text:
When Marilyn and Al retired, they both knew they wanted to use their free time to give back to their community and help people in Burlington County. For different reasons, they were both drawn to teaching English with Literacy NJ.

#ServiceSpotlight https://t.co/JRCL4RKEDm

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: Now, 28 years later, Camp No Worries hosts up to 100 children for a week at no cost to families. Its beloved traditions, including an "eat with anything but a utensil night," have grown with the camp and its campers.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: While she was in college, Kasey and her family opened Camp No Worries in the summer of 1995, hosting 14 children for 3 days and 3 nights after months of work, planning, and fundraising.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: Years after her treatment ended, Kasey still thought about this idea. When she was in college, she knew she could work with her family to use what they learned through her diagnosis, treatment, and recovery to give back to families in New Jersey.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text:
She remembers just how much she wanted ‚Äì and needed ‚Äì a place to step away from the isolation, fear, anger, and confusion she felt after her recovery.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: Together, these two bills tonight are about changing systems: our system of politics and our system of criminal justice. We can only do better for everyone when the systems are built to allow us to do that. Today was an important step in that direction (end)

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: This was a key part of what I heard when I did a series of listening sessions last year with community groups and law enforcement. There was a lot of common ground and common purpose. This bill is a step towards achieving that.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: This bill achieves that by banning practices like chokeholds and taking other steps to change the culture of our public safety so it works for everyone.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: Best practices, accountability, bringing our police and our communities closer together make for better, safer communities. That's our goal.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: This bill is actually the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act. It's named after Mr. Floyd because he serves as a reminder of a broken system. Broken for communities of color and broken for our men and women in uniform who serve and protect.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: That means we have a system that can truly tackle the big challenges of our time. One of those challenges is racial justice. That's where the second bill, the #JusticeInPolicingAct comes in.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: When our system doesn't work for you, it doesn't work. And when our system doesn't work, it doesn't work for you. We've seen that so many times over the past few years. This bill makes the changes we need to make the system work, and work for you.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: This bill does a lot of things, but it comes down to a few key categories: 1) it protects every American's right to vote and makes our voting systems safer, 2) it finally fights back against dark money, and 3) it strengthens our ethics laws to weed out bad actors.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: Let's start with #HR1, the #ForThePeople Act. This is a bill that I fought for even before I came to Congress. It's a bill that strikes at the core of what so many people I talk to every day are frustrated by: a system that works for big money and influence, not every day people.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: Tonight we're voting on two important bills in the House. I want to take a quick minute to tell you why in this moment it was critical we bring them up for a vote (thread)

tweet_text: It‚Äôs safe. It‚Äôs effective. It‚Äôs easy to transport. It‚Äôs one and done. That definitely checks all the boxes. Now let‚Äôs get some to New Jersey. https://t.co/kRy0nndtnY

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: Next the bill goes to the Senate. I hope they act swiftly because time is of the essence. You deserve this help, and I‚Äôm proud to have done my small part to deliver it.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: This isn‚Äôt a controversial bill. The US Chamber and the AFL-CIO support it. Big business leaders and small town mayors support it. It‚Äôs a bill that provides help because that‚Äôs what we do as Americans when we‚Äôre in a crisis; we help each other.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: RESCUE OUR MAIN STREETS - our small business aren‚Äôt just the places we work, they‚Äôre the centers of our communities. We improved the PPP and created a new fund for restaurants so our small businesses can weather the rest of the storm.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: RESCUE OUR KIDS - we‚Äôre all ready for our kids to go back to school in-person, but we have to make sure our schools and teachers are ready. This bill will make sure we do it right.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: RESCUE OUR COMMUNITIES - our counties and towns have been hit hard over the last year. When they lose revenue, you lose services. Congress can help and we did because we need to protect essential workers like first responders.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: RESCUE WORKING FAMILIES - millions of people are still out of work and millions more have been pushed to the brink of poverty. Rescue for them means $1400 direct payments and enhanced unemployment. It means help for food banks and other programs.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text:
That means we can‚Äôt just pass money to put more shots in arms -
though this bill does that and it‚Äôs going to help you get your vaccine faster. It means we need to tackle the crisis that came from COVID. I‚Äôll break it down:

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: First, let‚Äôs be clear about what this bill is: it‚Äôs a rescue plan. It‚Äôs in the name. But what are we rescuing the American people from? The totality of the #COVID pandemic.

tweet_text: Since the death of George Floyd, I held a town hall on issues impacting the Black community, and listening sessions with people across our community looking to make change. What I‚Äôve heard as been enlightening and inspiring.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: We know that it takes many hands to bend the arc of history towards justice. The echoes we see today are in the actions of young people speaking out and communities coming together peacefully to call for change and justice.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: The March on Washington brought collective action on a massive scale to television screens. We saw the dream of MLK and words of John Lewis lift up the voices of Black Americans simply looking for equal treatment. We see echoes of that today.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: I hope the President gets this right, because we can‚Äôt afford for him to be wrong. We‚Äôve already lost too many of our fellow Americans to double down a false strategy that clearly doesn‚Äôt work. Every day is a chance to reverse that. Let‚Äôs make it happen. (end)

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: So how do we fix this? We need more testing, we need guarantees that results are processed rapidly, we need to be able to surge testing capacities to hotspots as we see spikes, and we need to follow up with major investments in tracing and isolating.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: Testing is a tool. The goal isn‚Äôt to test ‚Äì the goal is to get data so you can act on it. Right now, we‚Äôre failing to act because we‚Äôre not taking the data we need to act seriously.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: If you‚Äôre forced to wait a week to get results, it makes contact tracing harder, which makes containment harder.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: So what about the claim that we‚Äôre testing more than before? Yes, that‚Äôs the case. But in too many places across the country, it takes a week or more to get those test results. At that point, those tests don‚Äôt have the impact they would if you got results within 24 hours.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: His obsession only with the total number of positive cases misses three major benefits of testing: to provide proper care to those that test positive, to see where the surges are, and to ensure we try to isolate/treat those infected and contact trace.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: Why? Because following recommendations from public health leaders brings down cases, not tests. If you have a rodent problem, you don‚Äôt solve it by turning the lights out. You solve it by finding out where the mice are coming from and sealing those areas off.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: In April, rate of positive tests in my state of NJ was around 50%. We were running fewer than 7k tests per day. We‚Äôve completed almost triple that per day now, but the number of positives is much lower than in April.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: Therefore halving the tests then halves the number of positive cases. In that line of thinking, doubling testing doubles the number of positive cases.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: First, let‚Äôs look at why it‚Äôs wrong. An important flaw of his logic is that it assumes that positivity rates for infections are constant across all levels of testing and throughout our country.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: Okay, we know this is wrong. I‚Äôve said that before. But since he keeps saying this, let‚Äôs dig into why it‚Äôs wrong and what it means. (thread) https://t.co/c8eh1dHcBP

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: This isn't how the math works. It's not how testing works. This isn't going to reopen our businesses and get our kids back to school. https://t.co/r294N3zDj7

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: Continuing recognizing the New Jerseyans who signed the Declaration of Independence ‚Äì next up is John Witherspoon who as president of the College of New Jersey, was the only active clergyman and college president to sign the Declaration.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
tweet_text: The next NJ founder I want to recognize on this #IndependenceDay is Francis Hopkins. He wasn‚Äôt just a lawyer and a judge; he was a musician and composer. He helped design the great seal of our country and went on to marry Ann Borden ‚Äì the founder of Bordentown.

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim

name: The Office of Congressman Andy Kim
